case_name: State of West Bengal v. Corporation of Calcutta

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 158 of 1956 filed by the State of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 158 of 1956. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated February 9, 1955 in Criminal Revision No. 282 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 9, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 282 of 1954,

facts.text: Calcutta High Court revision arose from Second Municipal Magistrate judgment dated December 15, 1953 in Case No. 2629C of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated December 15, 1953, of the Second Municipal Magistrate, Calcutta, in Case No. 2629C of 1952.

facts.text: On July 1, 1952, Corporation of Calcutta made application for summons against Director of Rationing and Distribution, Food Department, Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these. On July 1, 1952, the Corporation of Calcutta made an application for summons under s. 488 of Bengal Act III of 1923,

facts.text: Offence: using premises No. 259, Chitpur Road, Upper, for storing rice etc. under Bengal Rationing Order, 1943, without licence under s. 386 for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: which was substituted by West Bengal Act XXXIII of 1951, against the Director of Rationing and Distribution representing the Food Department of the Government of West Bengal . The offence companyplained of was for using or permitting to be used premises No. 259,

facts.text: Facts alleged by prosecution not denied by the Department.

anchor.surface_text: The facts alleged by the prosecution were number denied in behalf of the Department, which was in the position of the accused,

facts.text: Second Municipal Magistrate acquitted the accused on December 15, 1953 relying on Calcutta High Court decision in Corporation of Calcutta v. Sub-Postmaster.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing arguments for the parties the learned trial Magistrate passed an order acquitting the accused relying upon a decision of the Calcutta High Court in the case of The Corporation of Calcutta v. Sub-Postmaster, Dharamtala Post Office

facts.text: Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 282 of 1954 set aside acquittal on February 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent moved the Calcutta High Court in its revisional jurisdiction in Criminal Revision No. 282 of 1954, which was heard by a Division Bench companysisting of J. P. Mitter and S. N. Guha Ray, JJ.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court in September 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application for special leave to appeal from the aforesaid judgment and order of the High Court, and obtained special leave in September 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court heard the appeal on February 8, 9, 10, 1960.
Supreme Court judgment delivered on August 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 16.-The Judgment of Sinha, C.J., Imam and Shah, JJ., was delivered by Sinha, C. J

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, confirmed acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment under appeal set aside and the acquittal of the appellant companyfirmed.

facts.text: Prosecution under s. 386 of Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 for storing rice without licence.

anchor.surface_text: for the purpose of storing rice etc., under the provisions of the Bengal Rationing Order, 1943, without a licence under s. 386 for the year, 1951-52,

facts.text: Appellant is Director of Rationing and Distribution representing Food Department of Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: against the Director of Rationing and Distribution representing the Food Department of the Government of West Bengal .

facts.text: Storing rice for rationing scheme, governmental function.

anchor.surface_text: In storing the rice the appellant had acted in his official capacity and for carrying out the West Bengal Governments rationing scheme.

holdings.text: The penal section s.386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act does not apply to the Government either expressly or by necessary implication.

anchor.surface_text: The question most canvassed before us is whether the penal section invoked in this case applies to Government. It has been contended, and in our opinion rightly, that the provisions of the penal section neither by express terms nor by necessary implication are meant to be applied to Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies common law rule of construction that sovereign not bound unless express or nec impl; Privy Council binding pre-Constitution and continued.

holdings.text: The rule that the State is not bound by a statute unless expressly named therein or by necessary implication continues post-Constitution as good law.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we are definitely of the opinion that the rule of interpretation of statutes that the State is not bound by a statute, unless it is so provided in express terms or by necessary implication, is still good law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.372 continues all laws in force including common law rules of construction; no constitutional change abrogates it.

holdings.text: Article 372 continues pre-existing common law including the rule on sovereign immunity from statutes as 'law in force'.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 372 of the Constitution has specifically provided that subject to the other provisions of the Constitution all the laws in force in this country immediately before the commencement of the Constitution shall continue in force until altered or repealed or amended by a competent Legislature or by other competent authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Law in force' comprehensive per Art.13(3); includes common law adopted in India; distinguished from 'existing law'.

holdings.text: No offence committed by the appellant under s.386 as State not bound.

anchor.surface_text: The short question for determination in this appeal is whether any offence had been committed by the appellant, as alleged against him. If he was bound by the provisions of the Act to take out a licence

holdings.reasoning_summary: State/Department not bound by licensing requirement; prosecution misconceived.

holdings.text: Storing rice under rationing scheme is governmental function, not trade or business.

anchor.surface_text: In storing the rice the appellant had acted in his official capacity and for carrying out the West Bengal Governments rationing scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rationing/distribution ensures equitable food supply; sovereign duty, not commercial.

holdings.text: No necessary implication binds State under s.386/s.488 as fines go to State, rendering prosecution futile.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 81 of the Act of 1923 (or the corresponding s. 115 of the Act of 1951) the fines imposed by the Magistrate will not go to the Corporation but in the usual way to the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution results in fine to State itself; no efficacy lost if exempt; express exemptions ex majore cautela.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; acquittal confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed, the judgment under appeal set aside and the acquittal of the appellant confirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State not bound; no offence; prosecution not maintainable.

holdings.text: The rule is a rule of statutory construction, not dependent on royal prerogative.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the rule as applied in modern times, is really a rule of construction of statutes and is not dependent on royal prerogatives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evolution; applied in republics (US, Aus); presumed legislative intent.

holdings.text: Royal prerogative rule does not survive post-Republic; State bound unless expressly or nec impl exempt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No King/sovereign personified; Rule of Law binds State like citizens; ordinary construction applies (Wanchoo J. concurring opinion).

holdings.text: State exempt from penal fines by nec impl as fine goes to State itself.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Criminal sanctions (fine) futile against State; cannot prosecute self (Wanchoo J.).
